comments.body: Where is pandas making the default English? Haven't looked in detail but assumed this would be system dependent

I would expect that to be system independent (when programming, I'd rather have predictable results).

Code is implemented in `get_date_name_field()`:

https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/86e8f23be6d8496cb39ee836b5b02f5c91fda0ba/pandas/_libs/tslibs/fields.pyx#L102-L103
https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/86e8f23be6d8496cb39ee836b5b02f5c91fda0ba/pandas/_libs/tslibs/fields.pyx#L117-L118

`DAYS_FULL` and `MONTHS_FULL` are hard-coded in Pandas:

https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/blob/86e8f23be6d8496cb39ee836b5b02f5c91fda0ba/pandas/_libs/tslibs/ccalendar.pyx#L39-L48
The idea was for `day_name` to replace the depreciated `weekday_name` which defaulted to hardcoded english names (without localization support).
agree this should say the default is based on the locale
@jreback As you can see in the code snippets above, it is not based on the locale. The default is always English.
sure it does, just pass a locale name

@jreback Sorry, I do not understand your last comment. Are you still saying when no locale is passed as parameter then the default behavior is to use the system locale instead of always English? Or are you saying the default locale (English) should be specified instead of `locale=None` in the method declaration?

I am confused because it seemed to me you first asked to change the docstring to state that the default was the system locale instead of English (which is not true).
why don't you try both ways and see

@jreback Which both ways? Could you be more explicit about what you are trying to say? Explicit is better than implicit and words are free. :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye: 

I tried changing the system locale and verified the default behavior was to use English. Maybe I did something wrong, in which case, could you provide a better way to verify it? Also, I searched through the Pandas code and it seemed to me (as shown above), that the default is English, not system locale.
this is fully tested, why don't you have a look, just grep for day_name and see
@jreback Yeah, the tests seem to verify the same behavior: when locale is `None`, the default is always English, not system locale. I still do not get what you are trying to tell me then... :cry:
can you show here what you are running exactly

@jreback I do not think the code I am running is relevant here. Unless you refer to a trivial example like the one I added in the docstring (but why would you need that?):

```python
idx = pd.DatetimeIndex(start='2018-09-02', freq='D', periods=3)
idx.day_name()
```

Can you explain why you still say the default when `locale=None` is based on the system's locale? I checked the tests, the code and the behavior and everything seems to prove otherwise: the default when `locale=None` is English, and hence the proposed docstring. Did you check anything?
@jreback If you tell me exactly what changes to the current docstring you have on your mind (it seems other reviewers are okay with it), I may better understand what you are saying. :heart:

@Peque @jreback The default locale is English as `day_name` is meant to replace `weekday_name` which defaulted to english. So the docstring here is correct.

@Peque feel free to open up a new issue suggesting that `day_name` and `month_name` should default to system locale. This would be an API change.

@mroeschke Yeah, but I do prefer the current behavior, so I would rather not open that issue (and note I am not a native English speaker nor live in an English country).

When programming, I prefer everything in English by default. :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:

Gotcha @Peque. I hold a similar opinion for API transition sake.

Therefore, I think there's no action with this docstring here as far as I'm concerned.

> the original exception is re-raised here

That's my point.  We are definitely not communicating well.  I'm going to take that as a queue to step away from the desk for a few minutes.

OK, trying again.

My understanding of your suggestion is that you want to change:

```
try:
    result, inferred_tz = array_to_datetime(...)
except ValueError as e:
    try:
        result, inferred_tz = datetime_to_datetime64(...)
        return [...]
    except (ValueError, TypeError):
        raise e
```

to:

```
try:
    result, inferred_tz = array_to_datetime(...)
except ValueError as e:
    result, inferred_tz = datetime_to_datetime64(...)
    return [...]
```

My claim is that if we did that, then in cases where `datetime_to_datetime64` raises a `TypeError`, we would not re-raise `e` like we do in the status quo.
@jreback did this resolve the miscommunication?

again if datetime_to_datetime64 raises
wont it just bubble up which is the same thing as a reraise here

except (ValueError, TypeError) as e2:

comments.body:
Why is `tz` not a keyword? Because that is included in dtype? 
For me, it feels logical to have here the attributes of the array as keywords (that is also done in PeriodArray I think where freq is part of the dtype)

Not having `tz` in the `__init__` allows us to share a signature across DatetimeArray, TimedetlaArray, and PeriodArray. We're *close* to being able to share an implementation.

Since `tz` would be redundant with `dtype`, I found it easier to be strict and just allow dtype.

For PeriodArray, `freq` is actually redundant with `dtype`, but `freq` is already there for not having to re-infer for DTA and TDA, so it's probably best to support it.

Can you point to an example where it allows code sharing? (in the arithmetic code?) 
(as to me, it feels a bit as code smell to need the dtype here, which you actually don't need, other than to carry the attribute)

(didn't look in detail, but personally, I would rather consider having a separate constructor (like we now have `_simple_new`) that allows this code sharing. That would also make it explicit in the code that it is done that way, and keep the init more straightforward)

> Can you point to an example where it allows code sharing?

By code-sharing I meant merging `DatetimeArray.__init__ and TimedeltaArray.__init__`, but we don't currently do this.

> and keep the init more straightforward

I think that whether DatetimeArray gets the (maybe) tz from `tz=` or `dtype=` is mainly irrelevant for the complexity of the `init`. We'll still need to validate that tz against the maybe tz on the `data`, and we'll still need to normalize the tz.

And just to re-iterate, `tz` is not a "direct" property of the DatetimeArray. Rather it's a reference to `self.dtype.tz`, which is an Optional timezone. We don't set a `self._tz = tz` in the `__init__`.
I agree with @TomAugspurger here, this is an internal constructor and should just accept dtype

I was wondering if we still need this one. So it seems the only difference with the class init is that here a `tz` is allowed? 
It is somehow needed for code sharing between the different datetime-like arrays?
IIRC I briefly looked into this. It should be possible with a bit of effort.

Consolidating this discussion into 
https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/24024/files/e7505cd6424704122ff4fcfd438bef8b08085068#diff-b8a7b94d7e2ed5f7f109922e7bd3480c

(about `_simple_new`) the link you posted above seems to lead me nowhere (or problem of github with the huge PR)

No, I'm not sure. I'm writing up an issue on the constructors now. I'll include this point.

Just noticed... it'd be nice to leave a bunch of `TODO: Use super` for places like this.

Actually... I think Python2 will force us to make this changes when we switch inheritance to composition, since we won't be able to call the unbound method with a DatetimeIndex anymore (I think).
Hmm why was this necessary? Ideally everyone would reference `self.dtype.tz`

I think if you update the `tz` property defend below to be 

```python
    @property
    def tz(self):
        """
        Return timezone, if any.

        Returns
        -------
        datetime.tzinfo, pytz.tzinfo.BaseTZInfo, dateutil.tz.tz.tzfile, or None
            Returns None when the array is tz-naive.
        """
        # GH 18595
        return getattr(self.dtype, 'tz', None)

    @tz.setter
    def tz(self, value):
        # GH 3746: Prevent localizing or converting the index by setting tz
        raise AttributeError("Cannot directly set timezone. Use tz_localize() "
                             "or tz_convert() as appropriate")
```

then things will hopefully work.

comments.body: I simplified a bit the code here. Since `start` and `end` are either None or a `Timestamp` (L364-368), the use of `getattr` was not necessary.
is this some kind of list returned?

`generate_range` is an iterator function present in `pandas/tseries/offsets.py`.  So, here, `xdr` is an iterator (hence the conversion in a numpy array just after). This code was hidden in the previous version of `generate_regular_range`.

---
To be complete, in an earlier version of this PR I created two wrappers of `generate_regular_range`:

* `generate_timestamps_range`: wrapper of `generate_regular_range`, and used to call `generate_range` to handle the cases when freq was not an instance of `Tick`
* `generate_timedeltas_range`: wrapper of `generate_regular_range`

Both of them were really small and a bit unnecessary (especially `generate_timedeltas_range`). So it has been removed after a remark of @jbrockmendel https://github.com/pandas-dev/pandas/pull/33498#discussion_r408425826.
